comment: Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/76.25.114.53|76.25.114.53]] ([[User talk:76.25.114.53|talk]]): Unnecessarily limits definition. ([[WP:TW|TW]])

diff.*:
Line 4: Line 4:  
{{lead too short|date=June 2012}}
 
{{lead too short|date=June 2012}}
    −
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") describes the human or personal endeavor to answer the question of how one ought to live.
+
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or wrong). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. opposition to that which is good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
−   −
Morality has been interpreted to be the differentiation of intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are "good" (or right) and those that are "bad" (or wrong). The philosophy of morality is [[ethics]]. A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. ''Morality'' may also be specifically [[synonym]]ous with "goodness" or "rightness." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to morality (i.e. opposition to that which is good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.<ref>
